message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Learning to Teach in Cooperative Multiagent Reinforcement Learning
Paper Abstract: Collective human knowledge has clearly benefited from the fact that innovations by individuals are taught to others through communication. Similar to human social groups, agents in distributed learning systems would likely benefit from communication to share knowledge and teach skills. The problem of teaching to improve agent learning has been investigated by prior works, but these approaches make assumptions that prevent application of teaching to general multiagent problems, or require domain expertise for problems they can apply to. This learning to teach problem has inherent complexities related to measuring long-term impacts of teaching that compound the standard multiagent coordination challenges. In contrast to existing works, this paper presents the first general framework and algorithm for intelligent agents to learn to teach in a multiagent environment. Our algorithm, Learning to Coordinate and Teach Reinforcement (LeCTR), addresses peer-to-peer teaching in cooperative multiagent reinforcement learning. Each agent in our approach learns both when and what to advise, then uses the received advice to improve local learning. Importantly, these roles are not fixed; these agents learn to assume the role of student and/or teacher at the appropriate moments, requesting and providing advice in order to improve teamwide performance and learning. Empirical comparisons against state-of-the-art teaching methods show that our teaching agents not only learn significantly faster, but also learn to coordinate in tasks where existing methods fail.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "Multi-agent Systems":

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

The agents in a multi-agent system could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Agents have characteristics including autonomy (being at least partially independent and self-aware) and decentralization (with no agent designated as controlling the system).

## Recent Advances

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Research Areas

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment. Additionally, consensus dynamics studies how a group of agents interacting over a network can reach a common decision through local rules and information exchange.

Here are the search results for "Knowledge Transfer Machine Learning":

## Key Concepts

**Transfer Learning**: Transfer learning is a technique in machine learning in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

**Knowledge Distillation**: In machine learning, knowledge distillation or model distillation is the process of transferring knowledge from a large model to a smaller one.(no content)Knowledge distillation transfers knowledge from a large model to a smaller one without loss of validity, and as smaller models are less expensive to evaluate, they can be deployed on less powerful hardware.

## Applications

Transfer learning has been applied to cancer subtype discovery, building utilization, general game playing, text classification, digit recognition, medical imaging and spam filtering.(no content)Knowledge distillation has been successfully used in several applications of machine learning such as object detection, acoustic models, and natural language processing.

## Future Significance

Andrew Ng said in his NIPS 2016 tutorial that transfer learning would become the next driver of machine learning commercial success after supervised learning.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Multiagent Reinforcement Learning"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique)","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Google DeepMind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphacode"},{"title":"Category:Multi-agent systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Multi-agent_systems"},{"title":"AI agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-armed bandit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-armed_bandit"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"}]

## Multiagent Reinforcement Learning

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment. 

### Key Characteristics

Each agent is motivated by its own rewards and takes actions to advance its own interests; in some environments these interests are opposed to the interests of other agents, resulting in complex group dynamics.(no content)Multi-agent reinforcement learning is closely related to game theory and especially repeated games, as well as multi-agent systems.

### Research Focus

While research in single-agent reinforcement learning is concerned with finding the algorithm that gets the biggest number of points for one agent, research in multi-agent reinforcement learning evaluates and quantifies social metrics, such as cooperation, reciprocity, equity, social influence, language and discrimination.

### Key Challenges

The environment is not stationary anymore, thus the Markov property is violated: transitions and rewards do not only depend on the current state of an agent.

### Notable Concept: Autocurricula

An autocurriculum is a reinforcement learning concept that's salient in multi-agent experiments. As agents improve their performance, they change their environment; this change in the environment affects themselves and the other agents. The feedback loop results in several distinct phases of learning, each depending on the previous one.

### Real-World Applications

DeepMind announced the development of DeepNash, a model-free multi-agent reinforcement learning system capable of playing the board game Stratego at the level of a human expert.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Reinforcement Learning:

## What is Reinforcement Learning?

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Characteristics

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

A fundamental concept in RL is the exploration-exploitation tradeoff: To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications and Impact

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics.

## Related Subfields

Several specialized areas of RL exist, including:
- Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning. It focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Reinforcement Learning:

## What is Reinforcement Learning?

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Characteristics

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

A fundamental concept in RL is the exploration-exploitation tradeoff: To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications and Impact

It has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics.

## Related Subfields

Several specialized areas of RL exist, including:
- Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.
- Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning. It focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.
- Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Transfer Learning:

## Transfer Learning in Machine Learning

Transfer learning (TL) is a technique in machine learning (ML) in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

### History

In 1981, a report considered the application of transfer learning to a dataset of images representing letters of computer terminals, experimentally demonstrating positive and negative transfer learning.(no content)By 1998, the field had advanced to include multi-task learning, along with more formal theoretical foundations.(no content)Ng said in his NIPS 2016 tutorial that TL would become the next driver of machine learning commercial success after supervised learning.

### Applications

Transfer learning has been applied to cancer subtype discovery, building utilization, general game playing, text classification, digit recognition, medical imaging and spam filtering.(no content)In 2020, it was discovered that, due to their similar physical natures, transfer learning is possible between electromyographic (EMG) signals from the muscles and classifying the behaviors of electroencephalographic (EEG) brainwaves, from the gesture recognition domain to the mental state recognition domain.

### Related Concepts

The success of curriculum learning assumes that a model trained for an easier version of the problem can generalize to harder versions, so it can be seen as a form of transfer learning.

## Search Results for "Intelligent Agent"

Based on the web search, here are the key findings about intelligent agents:

### Core Definition

An intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously to achieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

### Key Characteristics

Intelligent agents operate based on an objective function, which encapsulates their goals, and are designed to create and execute plans that maximize the expected value of this function upon completion.(no content)Intelligent agents can range from simple to highly complex, with a basic thermostat or control system considered an intelligent agent, as is a human being, or any other system that meets the same criteria.

### Practical Examples

An agent is anything that perceives its environment using sensors and acts upon it using actuators—for example, a robot with cameras and wheels, or a software program that reads data and makes recommendations.

### Modern AI Agents

In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments, prioritizing decision-making over content creation and not requiring human prompts or continuous oversight.

The search results provide comprehensive information about intelligent agents across various domains, from basic control systems to advanced AI applications.

Links: [{"title":"Agent Communications Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent_Communications_Language"},{"title":"Short-range agent communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Short-range_agent_communications"},{"title":"Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_for_Intelligent_Physical_Agents"},{"title":"One-way voice link - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_voice_link"},{"title":"Interaction protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_protocol"},{"title":"Knowledge Query and Manipulation Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_Query_and_Manipulation_Language"},{"title":"Pragmatic theory of information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatic_theory_of_information"},{"title":"Defence Communication Services Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defence_Communication_Services_Agency"},{"title":"Fipa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FIPA"},{"title":"WE Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WE_Communications"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Agent Communication:

## AI Agent Communication

Agent Communication Language (ACL) consists of computer communication protocols that are intended for AI agents to communicate with each other.

### Key Protocols and Standards

In 2007, protocols of this nature were proposed which include FIPA-ACL (by the Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents, a standardization consortium).(no content)The most widely adopted of the FIPA standards are the Agent Management and Agent Communication Language (FIPA-ACL) specifications.

Another important protocol is KQML (Knowledge Query and Manipulation Language), a language and protocol for communication among software agents and knowledge-based systems.

### How They Work

Ontology based agent communication protocols use a common ontology to be used between agents. An ontology is a part of the agent's knowledge base that describes what kind of things an agent can deal with and how they are related to each other.(no content)These protocols rely on speech act theory developed by Searle in the 1960s and enhanced by Winograd and Flores in the 1970s.

### Modern Approaches

Generative AI based agent communication protocols such as NLIP do not require a shared ontology among communicating agents. In its stead, they use generative AI models to translate natural language text, images, videos or other modalities of data into a local ontology.

### Interaction Protocols

Within the fields of computer science and robotics, interaction protocols are possible communication scenarios between individual agents in multi-agent systems.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Agent Communication:

## AI Agent Communication

Agent Communication Language (ACL) consists of computer communication protocols that are intended for AI agents to communicate with each other.

### Key Protocols and Standards

In 2007, protocols of this nature were proposed which include FIPA-ACL (by the Foundation for Intelligent Physical Agents, a standardization consortium).(no content)The most widely adopted of the FIPA standards are the Agent Management and Agent Communication Language (FIPA-ACL) specifications.

Another important protocol is KQML (Knowledge Query and Manipulation Language), a language and protocol for communication among software agents and knowledge-based systems.

### How They Work

Ontology based agent communication protocols use a common ontology to be used between agents. An ontology is a part of the agent's knowledge base that describes what kind of things an agent can deal with and how they are related to each other.(no content)These protocols rely on speech act theory developed by Searle in the 1960s and enhanced by Winograd and Flores in the 1970s.

### Modern Approaches

Generative AI based agent communication protocols such as NLIP do not require a shared ontology among communicating agents. In its stead, they use generative AI models to translate natural language text, images, videos or other modalities of data into a local ontology.

### Interaction Protocols

Within the fields of computer science and robotics, interaction protocols are possible communication scenarios between individual agents in multi-agent systems.

Based on the web search results, here's information about the Coordination Problem:

## Game Theory Context

A coordination game is a type of simultaneous game found in game theory that describes the situation where a player will earn a higher payoff when they select the same course of action as another player.(no content)A typical case for a coordination game is choosing the sides of the road upon which to drive, a social standard which can save lives if it is widely adhered to. In this scenario, two drivers meet on a narrow dirt road, both have to swerve to avoid a head-on collision, and if both execute the same swerving maneuver they will manage to pass each other, but if they choose differing maneuvers they will collide.

## Coordination Failure

In economics and political science, "Coordination Failure" is a state of affairs in which agents' inability to coordinate their behavior (choices) leads to an outcome (equilibrium) that leaves all agents worse off than in an alternative situation that is also an equilibrium.(no content)In an economic system with multiple equilibria, coordination failure occurs when a group of firms could achieve a more desirable equilibrium but fail to because they do not coordinate their decision making.(no content)A manager can prevent coordination failure by either increasing financial incentives for employees or communicating with them, with communication being more effective than incentives.

Here are the search results for "Distributed Learning":

## Overview

Distributed learning is an instructional model that allows instructor, students, and content to be located in different, noncentralized locations so that instruction and learning can occur independent of time and place.

## Model Variations

The distributed learning model can be used in combination with traditional classroom-based courses and traditional distance education courses (referred to as blended learning), or it can be used to create entirely virtual classrooms.

## Key Characteristics

Distributed learning relies on collaboration to share knowledge and relies on technology to share, store, retrieve, and extend knowledge.

## Relationship to Other Terms

There is much confusion globally over distinctions between and definitions of distributed learning, distance education, open learning, e-learning, blended learning and other related terms.(no content)Distance education, the oldest and most commonly used of these terms, can be used to describe distributed learning.

## Related Concepts

The search results also show that "distributed learning" can refer to different concepts in different fields, including:
- **Distributed Artificial Intelligence (DAI)** – an approach to solving complex learning, planning, and decision-making problems
- **Distributed Practice** – a learning strategy where practice is broken up into a number of short sessions over a longer period of time
- **Federated Learning** – a machine learning technique where multiple entities collaboratively train a model while keeping their data decentralized

I've completed the web search for "Machine Learning Algorithm". Here's a summary of what I found:

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Types of Machine Learning Algorithms

Modern-day Machine Learning algorithms are broken into 3 algorithm types: Supervised Learning Algorithms, Unsupervised Learning Algorithms, and Reinforcement Learning Algorithms.

- **Supervised Learning**: Current Supervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of classification and regression.
- **Unsupervised Learning**: Current Unsupervised Learning Algorithms have objectives of clustering, dimensionality reduction, and association rule.
- **Reinforcement Learning**: Current Reinforcement Learning Algorithms focus on decisions that must be made with respect to some previous, unknown time and are broken down to either be studies of model-based methods or model-free methods.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Deep Learning

Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

The search results provide extensive information on various machine learning algorithms, their types, applications, and theoretical foundations.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Intelligent agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_agent"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Intelligent tutoring system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_tutoring_system"},{"title":"Machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_model"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in education - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_education"},{"title":"Education by algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education_by_algorithm"},{"title":"Self-play - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play"}]

I've completed a web search for "Teaching Machine Learning Agents." Here are the key findings:

## Main Training Approaches

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment to maximize a reward signal, and involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.

Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences, involving training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

## Educational Applications

Students can teach a machine learning agent which can learn to solve problems by demonstration and correctness feedback, as is the case in the APLUS system built with SimStudent. Evidence suggests that learning by teaching can be an effective strategy for mediating self-explanation, improving feelings of self-efficacy, and boosting educational outcomes and retention.

## Self-Learning Techniques
